reviewText:
We host parties every month or so, and tend to have two groups of people show up - my friends, who are mostly gamers, and my partner's, who mostly aren't. We have a pair of TVs set up in the lounge for mine to play on at these parties, and the rest tend to play Cards Against Humanity or socialise elsewhere in the house.

I was immediately impressed by how quickly both groups sat down in the lounge to give the Jackbox a go when I first bought it yesterday. We started with a round of Fibbage 2, which was loud, funny and silly enough for everyone to feel comfortable giving it a go without having to feel like they were joining the 'gamer' half of the crowd. Since you're controlling the games from your phone, nobody has to feel like they're out of their comfort zone with an Xbox controller or constantly waiting for a turn with a gamepad. Both the gamers and non-gamers in the group were able to play together, which is a really hard trick to pull off.

The games in the pack are varied enough to keep things interesting, and none of them are disappointing. I will say, though, that while the bomb disposal game is still pretty hilarious and engaging, it is a LOT harder than the others - the story mode is purely cooperative, and it can be a lot harder for less engaged players to feel like they're contributing. It also supports fewer players, which ended up cutting our playtime short in favour of the other titles.

I tried really hard to find a deal on this game before I picked it up, but I'm pretty happy with the $25 I paid for it in the end. We're going to be cracking it out again in the future, and it's a safe and reliable option for crowds who aren't necessarily full of gamer types.

reviewText: Lots of fun, just like the first pack! More Fibbage is always great; Bidiots if an interesting drawing game which is oddly strategic; Earwax is a fun take on using sound effects instead of writing; Quiplash is a lot of fun and the extra questions are appreciated compared to the original; and Bomb Corp is really different (cooperative! what is this!?) but very funny and challenging. Not necessarily any better than the first pack, but it's great to have an even bigger diversity of games to play so I would recommend this just as much as I recommend the first pack. Especially fun during the holiday season!

reviewText: Another set of great fun and frequently laugh-out-loud casual games best played with a large crowd, much more of an emphasis on letting the players to create their own comedy with their answers (Fibbage 2, Quiplash (literally a game about coming up with something funny/witty to order), Earwax) whilst the other two, Bidiots and Bomb Corp (a cheapass version of Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes) actually a bit gamier and more strategic than anything else Jackbox so far, but they'll still make you laugh (although they're best played with people willing to concentrate a bit more, Bidiots features a hilarious quickdraw element but a betting and bluffing element that might take a bit of explaining, Bomb Corp is a game of teamwork and shouting but also logic which might put people off, but it certainly adheres to the rule that if it's going well that's great but if it goes badly then it's increasingly funny). Good stuff.

reviewText:
Do you have a lot of friends that come over to your house? This is a perfect party game. Instead of an emphasis on gameplay skill or quick reflexes, these games are much more focused on wits, intelligence, and humor. It's perfect even for people who don't usually play video games. We all know that one time when we went over to a friend's house to play Mario Kart/ Super Smash Bros or something and he crushed all of us without even trying because he's the only one who owns the godamn game damnit. There's no such advantages available here, since the game is mainly trivia/ humor based.

Another great thing is you don't have to go fiddling around with any Xbox game controllers or anything like that. There is a cool browser based system where you just have to enter a code at jackbox.tv, using any browser. This means anyone with a smartphone can easily connect to the game they want to play as long as they have an internet connection. This is genius stuff, some of the games can have up to 8 players so instead of having to fiddle with a bunch of tangled wires/ teach everyone the controls, it is simple enough to set up and play. I've had good success using Valve's Steam Link paired with this game on a large TV with a group of people, it's always a good time!

The party pack comes with these 5 games below, although you'll probably only regularly play 2 or 3 of them.

Fibbage:
This game is played a lot I think, essentially some trivial question is given that nobody will likely know, it's pretty obscure stuff like What did Abraham Lincoln get as a present from this random governor on Independence Day?" or something similar

Essentially Apples to Apples or Cards Against Humanity in audio form

reviewText:
This is a great group of games, even better than the first party pack; Quiplash XL, Bidiots, and Earwax are my favorites, with the latter inspiring snickers all around. But there is one thing that needs to be changed.

FOR THE LOVE OF GOD, add the ability to kick players if you're the host! I can't tell you how many racist epithets, sexual idiocies, anti-semitic slurs, and similarly inappropriate names join my games when I'm streaming, and since I don't have the ability to kick people who do these sorts of things, I have two choices: give them what they want, or stop playing.

I understand that this was an oversight in the first Jackbox Party Pack, but this is the second one; you really should have known better.

Despite this, it's a fantastic game and I do recommend it, just be aware that streaming it is walking into a minefield.

reviewText:
As I said in my review for the first game, The Jackbox Party Pack is a wonderful idea for a party game. Unfortunately, the second pack is mostly disappointing.
My most immediate gripe is that it is such a shame to see this as a separate game, as opposed to DLC for the first party pack. Switching between the two during an evening is an annoying waste of time and shows that the developers aren't particularly interested in creating a long-lasting product. After purchasing it was also disheartening to see that the main menu was less stylised than the moving game boxes from the first game. A small problem, yes, but it just comes across as a lack of effort.

Moving onto the games themselves and it is clear that you and your friends will spend much less time with this selection of games than the last. Bidiots is too confusing and not gratifying enough to be a good party game. Bomb Corp also doesn't work well in this setting either, although when playing with just you and one friend it does have a small amount of fun to it. Talking of fun however, the rest of the games are more enjoyable. Unfortunately one of them is just more Fibbage. This does mean a wider selection of questions for those who love the game, but it is again sad to not see this as DLC for the first pack or integrated with Steam Workshop. The last of the games (Earwax and Quiplash) are the most enjoyable and fresh. However, they can both get repetitive more quickly. Earwax is fun to play to laugh at the silly sounds, but is rather lacking in real gameplay and Quiplash is perhaps too difficult to keep everyone laughing.

After mostly having an absolute blast with Jackbox Party Pack 1, it would have been nice to have seen more work gone into new games. However, overall the sequel just doesn't put as much effort in as its older brother and still lacks DLC and Steam Workshop support. Such a disappointment.

reviewText: It's a hard choice between Jackbox 1 and 2 if you don't want both. The first one has Fibbage and Drawful, this one has Fibbage 2, Quiplash, and Earwax. I didn't even get to trying Fibbage 2 yet and I would heartily recommend this pack for Quiplash and Earwax alone. Quiplash is basically a Cards Against Humanity with slightly fewer horrendously inappropriate prompts, where everyone votes and instead of playing an answer card you fill in your own blanks. Bomb Corp is passable and Bidiots is, while interesting, a not-quite-Drawful that gets extremely long in the tooth. If you have any remotely artistically inclined people, Drawful is still an excellent reason to get the first pack, but for my money, while it can be hit or miss on a round-to-round basis, Earwax is by far the hardest I've laughed at something in the last decade. It feels like I have a social life again, and I'm just using Skype screensharing. (Just make sure whoever's hosting has a decent upload rate, and I'd recommend at least 4 people for the best experience.)\n\nUltimately I think it boils down to whether you want to try to draw wolf parades, Cthulhu, and abstract concepts like burger time"

reviewText:
As I did when I reviewed the original Jackbox Party Pack, I'm going to divide this review into several little mini-sections: one for each game in the pack. The Jackbox Party Pack 2 is at its core, the same concept as its predecessor - a bunch of multiplayer mini-games where your cell phones are the input devices. The novelty here is that because your phones are the input devices, no one knows who typed or drew what except for the author. So now on with the review:

Fibbage 2
This is exactly the same game as the first time around, but with new questions. The game presents you with a weird fact, and you have to fill in the blank to try to trick your opponents into guessing your answer. Still pretty much Balderdash if you've ever played that.

Earwax
In earwax, you're presented with a category or an event or some similar thing and you have to choose a sound effect to match what's presented.  Then two player's selections go head to head and a judge votes on which is the most appropriate sound effect. I thought this game was pretty weak and the selectable sound effects started to repeat with just two or three rounds of play. Disappointing.

Bidiots
This was the strangest game in the pack. It seemed like an attempt to evolve on Drawful, which I believe to be the strongest game in the previous pack. In Bidiots, each player draws several art pieces based on several prompts. The pieces are assigned random monetary values, then players bid on each piece. Sometimes you'll be given clues to what a piece is worth based on the prompt that was used to draw it, but it's not always clear what prompt matches with what piece. And sometimes, you're not given a prompt at all. It turns one of the best games in the previous pack into one of the most unsatisfying experiences in Jackbox Party Pack 2. The rules are unclear and the games take way too long. The fun and silliness of drawing and guessing other's drawings turns into a boring bidding game. Bidiots was also a huge disappointment.

Quiplash XL
This is pretty much Earwax but without the sound effects. Players type in responses to the game's prompts to fill in the blank, then a judge votes on the best one. Quiplash still seemed somewhat lazy to me but was slightly more enjoyable than Earwax, only because a freeform response seemed more creatively satisfying to me than picking from pre-defined sound effects.

Bomb Corp.
I'm not sure who worked on this game whether it be a different group internally or a secret different studio altogether or something, but this game is so different from the others in the pack, both in visual aesthetic and gameplay quality. This is definitely the highlight of Jackbox Party Pack 2. In Bomb Corp. , each player is given a crucial step to disarming a bomb on their phone, but all steps need to be followed in order to diffuse the bomb correctly. It's a really fun excersise in communication and cooperation as all players need to work together to diffuse the bomb properly. This game was pretty cool

Summary
Even with the inclusion of the excellent Bomb Corp., The Jackbox Party Pack 2 was still a disappointment to me. Other than Bomb Corp., the pack felt like a rushed package with incomplete or creatively dull ideas resulting in unsatisfying gameplay experiences. The absense of the well-known You Don't Know Jack" mini-game was puzzling as well. I'm not sure if they tried to rush this package out in order to capitalize on the success of the first game or what

recommended: I'd strongly reccommend giving those a look first. But if you have
hoursPlayed: prepare yourself for a disappointment\n\nFor more game reviews

Earwax - One player chooses a question and the other players choose 2 sound effects that would fit as answers. It's not great as sometimes you have sounds that have NO relevence and it just becomes awkward and stupid at that point. There are some a few good moments however. 2.5/5

Quiplash XL - Great game if you have a bunch of people (4+). It's basically Cards against Humanity but you can choose whatever you want and people vote on which options they found the best. 4.5/5

Bomb Corp - Havent attempted yet.

Would I recommend it... Hold off

infinite party fun. quiplash and the expanded fibbage are worth the purchase price alone, but earwax and bomb corp just increase the amount of fun this package is at any get together. if you are social at all, BUY THIS GAME!

The Jackbox Party Pack 2 is an immense improvement on the original, if such was ever thought possible. Like the last pack, you get 5 games in one package.

Fibbage 2 which is the same as the original Fibbage only with new questions and a handy little DeFIBrilator" ability that eliminates all but two answers (one lie and the truth) but at the cost of halving the point values.

Earwax is a fun little game where one player selects a prompt from a pregenerated list of prompts while the other players select two choices from a list of predetermined sound effects that best fit the prompt (in their opinion). The players don't get to hear the sound cues until they's played on the screen so the players have to select the sounds by their written description. Earwax is played until one player reaches 3 points which makes for disappointingly short games some times.

Bidiots is probably the most difficult of the games available. There are a number of complicated rules and you can never really determine who's winning until the very end. It is fun to hear the different jingles for "Preditory Loans."

Quiplash XL is the same as the standalone Quiplash game (also highly recommended) only with more questions.

Finally Bomb Corp is an interesting 8-bit variant of "Keep-Talking-and-nobody-explodes." In this game
date: 1 to 4 players must work in tandem to defuse a series of bombs using the rules that appear on their devices.\n\nWithout a doubt this is a must for parties!"

This second installment in the jackbox party pack series is jam packed with five fantastic games, with none of them being dull like word spud was in the last game. Earwax was probably the one everyone thought was going to be the word spud of the group but in reality it is just as fun(ny) as all the others. Bomb corp. is a really fun and frantic gane where you and your buddies have several bombs to defuse, filing cabinets to sort, keypads to be figured out, and so much more, that everyone will enjoy it for years to come. Fibbage 2 is just as good as it was in the last installment with just as wacky categories to throw everyone off. Quiplash, the game where making an inside joke wins. Bidiots is the drawful of this party pack where everyone tries to buy a piece of art work for a lower price than listed. Overall the go-to party game for you and your friends!

reviewText: Excellent games, really fun for large groups. However Upon trying to play the game all devices connected stop responding and are disconnected from the room. It makes the games unplayable after about 3-5 minutes. Currently requesting a refund for technical reasons.

Fibbage 2: The gut-buster from the first Party Pack is back and better than ever! This trivia game for liars features some outrageously funny new facts — much more than the first Fibbage — and now your audience, whether it's your Twitch/Hitbox viewers or leftover partygoers, can join in on the fun too. The novelty might wear off once you start getting repeats, but that won't happen for a long while. 9/10\nEarwax: Cards Against Humanity but with sound effects" is a cool concept
date: but ultimately it falls short. It's not that the sounds are bad
recommended: and the prompts are pretty good too. The problem is the execution. You're given six random sounds and you have to pick two to fit the prompt — without being able to listen to them. Sometimes you don't get anything that fits. Sometimes this happens for the entire game
hoursPlayed: and you feel like you had no chance from the start. Jackbox doesn't lend itself well to games of chance. Another point against it that it doesn't stream well on Twitch (Hitbox
votesHelpful: and if you're trying to play it with friends on Skype
votesTotal: forget it. 3.5/10\nBidiots: Most people are calling this a worse Drawful. I respectfully disagree. "Art auction" seems like a bizarre concept for a party game
votesFunny: but Jackbox managed to pull it off. Each player gets two short descriptions that are eerily simular to everyone else's prompts. For instance
commentsCount: one player might get "eel" and "getting a tan"
column16: while another gets "garter snake" and "needs sunscreen". The challenge is figuring out which is which. It's honestly a lot more fun than it sounds
column17: and I'm sorry that I can't describe it any better. 8.5/10\nQuiplash XL: Quiplash is the best game that Jackbox has ever released. Yes
column18: even better than any of the You Don't Know Jack games. Even with repeat prompts
column19: you'll practically never run out of things to say. It's a freeform Cards Against Humanity
column20: and it succeeds in places where CAH doesn't — namely
column21: you get to make your own jokes
column22: which is perfect both for people who don't like vulgar humor and for those who want to kick it up a notch. 10/10\nBomb Corp: Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes
column24: there are extra twists to it
column25: but it just feels too similar (and inferior) to its direct competitor. Fun for a bit
column26: but ultimately a dud. 4.5/10\n\nOVERALL: 7.5/10 (average score: 7.1/10). Three hits and two misses
column27: but there's more than enough here to justify the $25 price tag."

reviewText: If you have  friends and drink, buy this game. Its fun, its simple to setup and fun! Buy it  and buy the first one too

Just like Jackbox Party Pack 1, this is a hit with my family.  My wife particularly enjoys Quiplash, but my favorite will always be Fibbage.  Having more than double the prompts of the original is a major benefit - I tend to play it a lot, with different people on different setups, so the questions tend to get repeated which isn't fun for the people who aren't in the know.

Earwax is kinda meh.  It's a hit with many of my teenage cousins who still think that farts are funny.

To be honest, I have yet to play Bidiots with anyone, and I'm not sure I know anyone who would be interested in playing it.  Part of me wishes they would have just repeated Drawful so I don't have to switch programs to play it when I've got a party going.

A team competitive mode for Bomb Corp. would be interesting.  That way we could get more than 4 players.

I was having issues the other day playing Quiplash with six people - for some reason the game would hang after the announcer acknowledged the group.

Is everything to be expected!

Bidiots: Haven't Played yet.

Quiplash XL: At the present time is bugged and couldnt play it.

Earwax: Some hilarious combinations. Great for some cheap laughs and an all around fun time. It made my brother laugh so hard he had to spit out his water. and he is almost 30.

Bomb Corp: Havent played, but i can say it kind of looks like the black sheep of the litter.

10/10

Playing the games: As long as everyone has some wifi/cellular connection and a phone (apple or andriod), iPad, or computer, it is super easy to sign in with the four letter room code and play.

After only playing a few times I think this is the most essential modern party game there is. I love serious tabletop games but when people want to drink and be silly this is the way to go. Quiplash is a better version of Cards Against Humanity.

After an excellent Skype session with friends last night I can confidently say that this is brilliant.

Fibbage 2: Same as in the original game but with a few more bells and whistles, still great 4/5
Earwax: Turned out to be the highlight of the night, extremely funny 5/5
Bidiots: A little confusing at first but eventually got into it 3/5
Quiplash XL: The classic. Pure entertainment every game 5/5
Bomb Corp: Another big surprise, incredibly tense and lots of fun 4/5

Absolutely no duds this time around (Word Spud...) so I can definitely recommend this for streamers or house parties!
Such an awesome party pack - it kept a wide range of people entertained for hours during Christmas!  I can't wait to get another group together to play it again!

Played this with a full house of people during 2015/2016 new years and it was a blast!

However quiplash still has this nasty tendency of not working when you start it up. It would just black screen after all players are ready.

We found that a temporary fix would be to restart the computer and boot up, hope it gets patched in a future update.

Aside from that glitch over all amazing party games.
The  selection of games makes this a better value and more fun.
Perfect, my friends and I enjoy all the games in this party pack.

This game and the first one are ridiculous fun when playing with a large group of people. My only complaint is that sometimes the communication from computer to mobile devices is a little slow. I've had it take off chunks of time when trying to respond to certain games.\n\nHowever, the majority of it is perfect. Legit fun for hours!

Almost universally loved by gamers and non-gamers alike. I think it's worth owning this and the first one, but if you only pick up one, I'd get this one for Fibbage 2. I like Bidiots a lot, but many of my friends prefer Drawful from the first game.

Love this game. The game selection is a lot better than that of the original Jackbox Party Pack. Being able to use smartphone and tablet as a controller really opens the game up to everybody. I've played this with my grandmother and mom and had just as much fun as I did playing with friends. That's something you don't find often.

Perfect for gamers and non-gamers alike. No matter who I'm hanging out with, whether online or all sitting in a room together, everyone has a great time with Jackbox games, this one included. I recommend picking it up on sale if you're unsure. Can't wait to see more from this company, their consistent awesomeness has made all of their games a day-one purchase for me.

My only complaint is that Earwax and Bidiots are nearly impossible to play with stream viewers. There's usually a ~15 second delay and both of these games require a near-immediate response to be fully caught up with everything going on.

You can watch some highlights from one of my playthroughs here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RHd7106edEY
That moment when you can't think of an answer for Quiplash:\n\nWhere's the Lie For Me button!?""

A great assortment of games for a okay price. Each game brings fun to the table. From picking surprisingly fitting sounds to match a given prompt to defusing bombs, this pack provides fun for any party night.

Small word of warning though. If you plan to play this with only a certain group of friends or two, I would not recommend playing Quiplash for a majority of the time. I know people say it's the funnest in the pack, but there is one key flaw, not with the game though. Friends may tend to repeat jokes. At first it may seem a bit funny but after spending a lot of time in it you may start to grow tired of what is a fantastic game in the pack. I would recommend not having this (or possibly Fibbage 2, it can apply there as well) to be your most played games in the pack.

To me the games that let this pack shine the most are Bomb Corp and Biddiots.
Bomb Corp is a co-op game where each player gets a set of instructions (or some other form of handicap that requires the group to work together) that must be followed to diffuse bombs. If one person messes up ...  BOOOOM! Back to the start of that day. It can be frustrating but fun at the same time, plus beating that one day you were stuck on is very rewarding.

Biddiots is a game where each player must draw 2 pieces of art and then bid on everyone else's art. The goal is to make the most money by buying expensive pieces for cheap. The screw mechanic from You Don't Know Jack is present in this game where you can FORCE another player into buying an art piece. It helps if you're about to win a piece you don't want or if you want to spike up the price of your piece, but be careful. If you use a screw on a player who can't bid that high, then the screw is wasted.

Overall this and the first game pack is fun. It has a lot of possibilities when playing with a pretty large crowd, plus with the new Audience function in some games it provides humongous meetups / events to have a fun game going. I could not recommend this more
This is such a great game! I probably don't prefer it over Jackbox Party Pack 1, but it's great!

Surprisingly, this set of games is more fun than the first Party Pack!
Played it only with (3) friends as a trial run, and we had a blast. Some games you really need like 5-8 people, but all the games were great!

Totally worth picking up and throwing on the bigscreen.

So far I only played Bomb Corp, and based on that poorly programmed game alone i am not recomending this. The game has several common game breaking bugs in the last 3 days, all of them relating to the copier segments. Sometimes when the overheat button is on, meaning dont touch anything or you lose, it never goes away, which means you just lost and have to restart. Then, on Day 15, not only can this happen, but the copier segment often just doesnt start, this has happened repeatedly and is inexcusable.\n\nEDIT: so i legit forgot I made this review, the game has long sicne been fixed, i now fully reccomend the game, bomb corp is fun now that it works, I actually like ear wax, fibbage is great of course, i really enjoy bidiots even though i prefer drawful, and as for quiplash, well, if you can get a full group it is good, but even with 4 people that is not a large enough number to really enjoy it
I stream it and play online with friends. Although its difficult with some games, we get loads of fun anyways.\n\nDefinitely get it if you're in a group and looking to play a game

Jackbox is a lot of fun for having friends over—like four board games, but all you have to do is turn on the game. No pieces to lose or complicated set-up. Quiplash and Fibbage are especially fun with groups, though all the games are enjoyable. Make sure you have some way to stream the game to a TV or put it on a laptop everyone can see, though. Apple TV, chromecast, etc. will all work.
Would have preferred this be DLC to the original game, but is still a lot of fun with a big group of friends.
